name: SpaceX Key Fob
description:
Created for SpaceX fans... a simple key fob using the logo styling to form the outline shape of the key fob. They look great printed in 2 or 3 colors. Just pause your machine at the relevant times mid-print and swap the filament color.

To make the SpaceX Key Fob multi colour (based on standard scale use) please use the following as a guide:

spacex_2.stl
This is the 2 colour version. The base is 2.85mm tall so swap your filament at 3mm through the print (if you can pause by mm build height) and change the filament colour. If you cannot pause in this way you will need to pause the machine manually. In this case watch the print and, when you can see the base surface is fully covered and the machine starts only printing the lettering manually pause your machine, swap the filament then restart to complete the print. 

spacex_3.stl
First pause as above. The second change is just 1mm build height later (3.85mm) which will not take long at all because to reach as the lettering is all that is being printed at that stage. Use the same principal as above by watching the lettering closely as it is formed. The final part is only the long part of the X. That prints an additional 1mm higher than the rest of the text so can be printed in a third colour.    

This is a small, quick and easy print that won't use much filament. At standard scale the fob is 85mm in length including the key ring attachment part. This makes the fob a similar length to many car remote controls. 

Please note that the design can be scaled up or down however scaling down is likely to affect the sharpness of the text as not all machines will be able to print as finely / precisely as this would require. 

This is a fun little print that will be appreciated by any SpaceX fan. 

Please refer the images and print instructions provided for additional information and share photos of your printed Key Fobs for other members to see. 

And, check out the rest of my fun and practical designs!
description_html:
Created for SpaceX fans... a simple key fob using the logo styling to form the outline shape of the key fob. They look great printed in 2 or 3 colors. Just pause your machine at the relevant times mid-print and swap the filament color.

To make the SpaceX Key Fob multi colour (based on standard scale use) please use the following as a guide:

spacex_2.stl
This is the 2 colour version. The base is 2.85mm tall so swap your filament at 3mm through the print (if you can pause by mm build height) and change the filament colour. If you cannot pause in this way you will need to pause the machine manually. In this case watch the print and, when you can see the base surface is fully covered and the machine starts only printing the lettering manually pause your machine, swap the filament then restart to complete the print.

spacex_3.stl
First pause as above. The second change is just 1mm build height later (3.85mm) which will not take long at all because to reach as the lettering is all that is being printed at that stage. Use the same principal as above by watching the lettering closely as it is formed. The final part is only the long part of the X. That prints an additional 1mm higher than the rest of the text so can be printed in a third colour.

This is a small, quick and easy print that won't use much filament. At standard scale the fob is 85mm in length including the key ring attachment part. This makes the fob a similar length to many car remote controls.

Please note that the design can be scaled up or down however scaling down is likely to affect the sharpness of the text as not all machines will be able to print as finely / precisely as this would require.

This is a fun little print that will be appreciated by any SpaceX fan.

Please refer the images and print instructions provided for additional information and share photos of your printed Key Fobs for other members to see.

And, check out the rest of my fun and practical designs!

name: DesktopHero Prototypes!
description:
Prototypes for the miniature creator DesktopHero! 

You can help me out by printing the miniature and posting pictures of your make! Be sure and include details such as: 
- Which version of the file you printed
- Any changes you made to the file (such as resizing)
- What printer you used
- Print settings

To follow along with development and join the DesktopHero community, check out the Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/

name: Revolver Caddy
description:
The Revolver Caddy is a spinning caddy that looks like a Six-Shooter Revolver... and is a practical and fun way to store everything from pens / pencils at home or in the office as well as making a great tooth brush / tooth paste holder. 

And, they make a fantastic 'fidget thing' with a number of practical applications... everyone enjoys spinning them!  

This is a two part design with a base and a caddy. A well printed Revolver should spin freely on it's base. It is recommended that the base is secured to a table/desk/bench using a non marking removable adhesive like Blu-Tack or double sided tape. Using a foam rubber pad is another option but is not as effective at securing the base as an adhesive... and a secure base means you can achieve a rapid Revolver spin without the base moving. 

The Revolver Caddy is quite a lengthy print as the Caddy part in particular has a lot of outline surfaces which always print slower than infill. However, the result makes it all worthwhile... and they look great printed in any color. 

Print one or more to use yourself but they will also make a unique gift for someone who has 'everything'... but they won't have everything until they have one of these!

They look very cool and will prove themselves of value and fun in the office or workshop, in classrooms (for pens etc.) or even bathrooms (as a toothbrush holder). 

This is an easy print that should be no issue on almost any machine. Post printing please ensure all contact surfaces are clean and smooth to ensure the Revolver Caddy spins well. Applying a light silicone lubricant will also benefit how well and fast it spins. 

Refer to the instructions provided and images for additional information and please post images of your Revolver Caddy in use for other members to see. 

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.   

Tips: Tips are not expected but are appreciated as they help offset my filament costs as much as anything else. However, as I live outside the USA tips cannot be sent to me via PayPal.Me as that service is not supported in my region and this is beyond Thingverse's control. If you feel like sending a tip please use regular PayPal and send it to muzz64nz@gmail.com and, to those who do,  thanks in advance!

details:
Summary

The Revolver Caddy is a spinning caddy that looks like a Six-Shooter Revolver... and is a practical and fun way to store everything from pens / pencils at home or in the office as well as making a great tooth brush / tooth paste holder.

And, they make a fantastic 'fidget thing' with a number of practical applications... everyone enjoys spinning them!

This is a two part design with a base and a caddy. A well printed Revolver should spin freely on it's base. It is recommended that the base is secured to a table/desk/bench using a non marking removable adhesive like Blu-Tack or double sided tape. Using a foam rubber pad is another option but is not as effective at securing the base as an adhesive... and a secure base means you can achieve a rapid Revolver spin without the base moving.

The Revolver Caddy is quite a lengthy print as the Caddy part in particular has a lot of outline surfaces which always print slower than infill. However, the result makes it all worthwhile... and they look great printed in any color.

Print one or more to use yourself but they will also make a unique gift for someone who has 'everything'... but they won't have everything until they have one of these!

They look very cool and will prove themselves of value and fun in the office or workshop, in classrooms (for pens etc.) or even bathrooms (as a toothbrush holder).

This is an easy print that should be no issue on almost any machine. Post printing please ensure all contact surfaces are clean and smooth to ensure the Revolver Caddy spins well. Applying a light silicone lubricant will also benefit how well and fast it spins.

Refer to the instructions provided and images for additional information and please post images of your Revolver Caddy in use for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

Tips: Tips are not expected but are appreciated as they help offset my filament costs as much as anything else. However, as I live outside the USA tips cannot be sent to me via PayPal.Me as that service is not supported in my region and this is beyond Thingverse's control. If you feel like sending a tip please use regular PayPal and send it to muzz64nz@gmail.com and, to those who do, thanks in advance!

Print Settings

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

                                            <p class="detail-setting printer"><strong>Printer: </strong>
                     <div><p><a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.amazon.com/MakerBot-MP07825EU-Replicator-3D-Printer/dp/B01LZSUQKL?dchild=1&keywords=makerbot&qid=1618268375&sr=8-1-spons&psc=1&spLa=ZW5jcnlwdGVkUXVhbGlmaWVyPUEzQ0ZNMjlZVFUwSzdYJmVuY3J5cHRlZElkPUEwNTcyODkzVEM0SlZJS1BVUFlHJmVuY3J5cHRlZEFkSWQ9QTA&tag=tv-nothing-20">MakerBot Replicator</a>+</p></div>

Rafts:

Yes

                                            <p class="detail-setting supports"><strong>Supports: </strong>
                     <div><p>Doesn't Matter</p></div>

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

                                            <p class="detail-setting infill"><strong>Infill: </strong>
                     <div><p>PLA / 2 Shells / 10% or greater infill</p></div>



Notes:

Easy print... but it will take a while. There are two parts, the base and the caddy. The caddy part has a lot of outlines / surface 'distance' so the print is quite long but the result is very pleasing and worthwhile.

Using a Raft is recommended to ensure the base of the print is nice and flat which is necessary for a good result.

Post-Printing

A couple of tips for a great Revolving Caddy...

Check the surfaces of both parts that will run against each other and remove any excess filament / raised areas to create a smooth easy spin. Applying a light (silicone) lubricant to the contact surfaces will also help your Revolving Caddy spin freely.

Securing the base plate in position is also recommended to ensure it won't spin with along the caddy part. To do this using a small amount of 'Blu-Tack' or similar non marking pressure sensitive adhesive is very effective. Alternatives, albeit not necessarily as effective, are double sided tapes or a foam rubber pad.

name: Geckoz
description:
Geckoz are... fun and super flexible just like a... gecko!

This is a simple one piece print that, with a precisely sliced file and printed on a well set up accurate machine, will create super flexible Geckoz. The images provided show the results...

Apart from being another unique example of what can be produced with 3D printing Geckoz are fun things to have around home, at work or in school. They look great printed in any color... but once you print one you're sure to want to print more!

Geckoz get their flexibility from 'sliding links' that will extend / contract depending on the pressure placed on them. At standard scale contracted Geckoz are 195mm in length... but fully extended they measure 230mm. That additional 35mm makes a big difference in flexibility to make the parts rotate to greater angles. The clearances designed in have been intentionally left loose to accommodate most printers... this means the scale can be reduced on well set up machine to potentially 75 - 80% of the standard scale but remain free / loose to move.  

Two versions have been provided. If you have a large enough build plate (over 200mm in length) you can use the 'straight' version. If you have a smaller build plate use the 'curled' version... or if you want to print super sized Geckoz this version will also be of use to make the print as big as possible even on a large build plate. The curved version is 144mm x 123mm at 100% scale.   

This is a super flexible one-piece-print. The designed in clearances should make it readily printable with no issues on most well set up PLA machines with a filament fan and reasonable bridging capability. No supports are required and raft is recommended to avoid the risk of damaging your Geckoz when you take them off your build plate. 

Please refer to the images and instructions provided for additional information... and make sure you post images of your Geckoz in all sorts of places!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs including the following: 

'Bugz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1904654

'Minisaurs' https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476792

description_html:
Geckoz are... fun and super flexible just like a... gecko!

This is a simple one piece print that, with a precisely sliced file and printed on a well set up accurate machine, will create super flexible Geckoz. The images provided show the results...

Apart from being another unique example of what can be produced with 3D printing Geckoz are fun things to have around home, at work or in school. They look great printed in any color... but once you print one you're sure to want to print more!

Geckoz get their flexibility from 'sliding links' that will extend / contract depending on the pressure placed on them. At standard scale contracted Geckoz are 195mm in length... but fully extended they measure 230mm. That additional 35mm makes a big difference in flexibility to make the parts rotate to greater angles. The clearances designed in have been intentionally left loose to accommodate most printers... this means the scale can be reduced on well set up machine to potentially 75 - 80% of the standard scale but remain free / loose to move.

Two versions have been provided. If you have a large enough build plate (over 200mm in length) you can use the 'straight' version. If you have a smaller build plate use the 'curled' version... or if you want to print super sized Geckoz this version will also be of use to make the print as big as possible even on a large build plate. The curved version is 144mm x 123mm at 100% scale.

This is a super flexible one-piece-print. The designed in clearances should make it readily printable with no issues on most well set up PLA machines with a filament fan and reasonable bridging capability. No supports are required and raft is recommended to avoid the risk of damaging your Geckoz when you take them off your build plate.

Please refer to the images and instructions provided for additional information... and make sure you post images of your Geckoz in all sorts of places!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs including the following:

'Bugz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1904654

'Minisaurs' https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476792

The clearances designed in have been intentionally left loose to accommodate most printers... this means the scale can be reduced on well set up machine to potentially 75 - 80% of the standard scale but remain free / loose to move.

Two versions have been provided. If you have a large enough build plate (over 200mm in length) you can use the 'straight' version. If you have a smaller build plate use the 'curled' version... or if you want to print super sized Geckoz this version will also be of use to make the print as big as possible even on a large build plate. The curved version is 144mm x 123mm at 100% scale.

This is a super flexible one-piece-print. The designed in clearances should make it readily printable with no issues on most well set up PLA machines with a filament fan and reasonable bridging capability. No supports are required and raft is recommended to avoid the risk of damaging your Geckoz when you take them off your build plate.

Please refer to the images and instructions provided for additional information... and make sure you post images of your Geckoz in all sorts of places!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs including the following:

'Bugz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1904654

'Minisaurs' https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476792

'Z-REX' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1594269

'Ratz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1532944

'Crocz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:941177

'Woodpeckerz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1155168

'Eaglez' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:963892

'Catz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:988088

'Scorpionz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001286

Tips: Tips are not expected but are appreciated as they help offset my filament costs as much as anything else. However, as I live outside the USA tips cannot be sent to me via PayPal.Me as that service is not supported in my region and this is beyond Thingverse's control. If you feel like sending a tip please use regular PayPal and send it to muzz64nz@gmail.com and, to those who do, thanks in advance!

Print Settings

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 20% or more infill recommended


Notes:

Raft is recommended for ease of print removal from the build plate and to help ensure the fingers and toes aren't damaged during the process. Do not use any automated support or the joints could be fused.

Post-Printing

Stretch your Geckoz!

The Geckoz design features extending joints so make sure you free each joint (good prints should come off the build plate free / loose) then check each link slides back / forth freely... so you can stretch them out.

If the links aren't free, gently wiggle to help free it up and add some light lubricant (silicone) spray to help the parts slide freely. This will help allow your Geckoz flexibility.

name: Dragonborn Warlord (multiple poses)
description: A Dragonborn Warlord for your gaming pleasure! Created and posed in DesktopHero. This mini is part of a series designed to increase awareness of DesktopHero, which allows you to customize minis like this one and export as an STL for free. Check out the Kickstarter! I'm including the DesktopHero character files (.dhc) in case you want to load them into DesktopHero and change the weapons or tweak the clothing or pose. Dragonborn Warlord originally created by pmains1 using DesktopHero. Credits for individual assets: dazle (Basic Leather Pauldron), backer71 (Dragon Head), Melic (BasePave1).

name: No-Supports Nativity Set
description:
Well, my wife and I actually wanted to make this an advent calendar, but I'm having trouble designing a good box for them. So for now, it's just a nativity set!

All of these parts can be printed without supports.

When assembling the stable, pop the pillars onto the base with the top nubs on the inside. The roof fits over the top. 

Includes:
 - Mary
 - Joseph
 - Baby Jesus
 - Manger
 - Stable
 - Donkey
 - Shepherd
 - Wise Man
 - Angel
 - Star
 - Sheep (standing)
 - Sheep (lying down)

This is a work in progress, so check back as I add more models! Comments welcome. :)

Edit: Added sheep, resized all pieces to a reasonable printing size
Edit: Thickened sheep and donkey legs for better printing
Edit (12/12/17): Added stable and star, thickened manger for better printing

name: Armored Warrior (multiple poses)
description: A daunting warrior in armor, with a sword to swing and honor to defend! For tabletop games and what have you. Inspired from reading about the Shardplate and Shardblades in The Way of Kings, and based on this drawing by BeLew32. Included are multiple poses. If you don't see what you want, you can either request an alternate pose, or download the .blend file, which contains the rigged mesh, and pose it yourself. As always, upload your makes - I love to see how you use them!
description_html:
A daunting warrior in armor, with a sword to swing and honor to defend! For tabletop games and what have you.

Inspired from reading about the Shardplate and Shardblades in The Way of Kings, and based on this drawing by BeLew32.

Included are multiple poses. If you don't see what you want, you can either request an alternate pose, or download the .blend file, which contains the rigged mesh, and pose it yourself.

As always, upload your makes - I love to see how you use them!
details:
Summary

A daunting warrior in armor, with a sword to swing and honor to defend! For tabletop games and what have you.

Inspired from reading about the Shardplate and Shardblades in The Way of Kings, and based on this drawing by BeLew32.

Included are multiple poses. If you don't see what you want, you can either request an alternate pose, or download the .blend file, which contains the rigged mesh, and pose it yourself.

As always, upload your makes - I love to see how you use them!

Print Settings

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Print needs supports, but you might try printing the model on its back to minimize support material.

data.content:
A daunting warrior in armor, with a sword to swing and honor to defend! For tabletop games and what have you.

Inspired from reading about the Shardplate and Shardblades in The Way of Kings, and based on this drawing by BeLew32.

Included are multiple poses. If you don't see what you want, you can either request an alternate pose, or download the .blend file, which contains the rigged mesh, and pose it yourself.

As always, upload your makes - I love to see how you use them!

data.notes:
I printed using these settings.

Print needs supports, but you might try printing the model on its back to minimize support material.

name: Robotic Fire Suppressor
description:
Day 47: A robotic fire-suppressant node. The withdrawn version can be placed as a counter, then replaced when something (like, say, a flame thrower being used in the vicinity) sets it off, dousing everything in the region with extinguisher foam and generally cramping everyone's style.

This model is scaled for standard miniature gaming (compatible with Games Workshop, Reaper, CMON, Hero Forge, and other major ranges), and prints without support. The New Dominion Enforcer model shown in the background is [available here](http://www.illgottengames.net/products/wayfarer-tactics-new-dominion-reinforcements).
 
For those of you thinking about [supporting us on Patreon](https://www.patreon.com/illgottengames), our patrons get special weekly model releases, access to new storefront releases and our entire back catalog, plus licensing options to sell printed versions of our designs.

name: Arcane Energy Collector
description:
Day 41: Arcane Energy Collector. This came from a dream I had the other night. We’re always thinking about how to define the existence and function of magic in our Wayfarer multiverse setting, and the dream was about how magical energy, when spent to power a spell effect, has to shunt into the nearest reality where it can be collected. Often, this can result in it being collected by gestalt hell dimensions, nightmare realms, horrors from beyond space and time, et cetera, becoming “demonic energy” and feeding those malignant id-universes. As such, the Old Dominion (Arcane Division) set up these special pylons that collect and store magical energy before it can be corrupted (and to keep it from rupturing branar stability, which is also a danger). Since the New Dominion took over (and disbanded the Arcane Division), these stations have largely fallen into disrepair.

This model is scaled for standard miniature gaming (compatible with Games Workshop, Reaper, CMON, Hero Forge, and other major ranges), and prints without support. Two versions are included (regular and weathered).
 
For those of you thinking about [supporting us on Patreon](https://www.patreon.com/illgottengames), our patrons get special weekly model releases, access to new storefront releases and our entire back catalog, plus licensing options to sell printed versions of our designs.

name: Recon Drone
description:

The model in the background was made in DesktopHero 2.0.

For those of you thinking about [supporting us on Patreon](https://www.patreon.com/illgottengames), our patrons get special weekly model releases, access to new storefront releases and our entire back catalog, plus licensing options to sell printed versions of our designs.

name: Evergreen Tree
description:
Day 34: A basic evergreen tree which can be placed with or without a trunk. Also, our [Nine Worlds campaign is live on Kickstarter!](https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/292543184/nine-worlds) [](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xPmxmm-Zt6Q) Plus, we've just released the beta for our Nine Worlds skirmish wargaming rules, and [you can get that as a free download here](http://www.illgottengames.net/nine-worlds).

This model is scaled for standard miniature gaming (compatible with Games Workshop, Reaper, CMON, Hero Forge, and other major ranges), and prints support free. This is part of our [Nine Worlds collection](https://www.thingiverse.com/dutchmogul/collections/nine-worlds) (more info there).

For those of you thinking about [supporting us on Patreon](https://www.patreon.com/illgottengames), our patrons get special weekly model releases, access to new storefront releases and our entire back catalog, plus licensing options to sell printed versions of our designs.

name: House Etryn Puritan, 28mm Miniature
description:
A bit of a work in progress. Part of my ongoing quest to print table-top quality, 28mm scale miniatures on my replicator. The printed version came out a little better than I had expected, though I'll compare this with a Shapeways version as soon as I get that in the mail.  

This guy is printed in pieces so that he can be assembled in slightly different poses. That was maybe the most successful part of my prototype.
instructions: Printed at a .1 layer height in black ABS, assembled with superglue, and painted with model acrylics
